member.name: T:Westwind.BusinessFramework.BusinessObjectOptions
member.summary: Contains public options that can be set to affect how the business object operates

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.BusinessObjectOptions.ThrowExceptions
member.summary: Determines whether exceptions are thrown on errors or whether error messages are merely set.

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.BusinessObjectOptions.TrackingMode
member.summary:
Determines how LINQ is used for object tracking.
In connected mode all changes are tracked until SubmitChanges or Save is called. Save() reverts to calling SubmitChanges.
In disconnected mode a new context is created for each data operation and save uses Attach to reattach to a context.
Use Connected for much better performance use disconnected if you prefer atomic operations in the database with individual entities.

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.BusinessObjectOptions.ConnectionString
member.summary:
Optional Connection string that is used with the data context
Note: This property should be set in the constructor/Initialize of the business object.
If blank the default context connection string is used.

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.BusinessObjectOptions.ConflictResolutionMode
member.summary: Determines the default Conflict Resolution mode for changes submitted to the context.

member.name: T:Westwind.BusinessFramework.ConflictResolutionModes
member.summary: Determines how conflicts on SubmitChanges are handled.

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.ConflictResolutionModes.None
member.summary: No Conflict resolution - nothing is done when conflicts occur. You can check Context.ChangeConflicts manually

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.ConflictResolutionModes.ForceChanges
member.summary: Forces all changes to get written. Last one wins strategy

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.ConflictResolutionModes.AbortChanges
member.summary: Aborts all changes and updates the entities with the values from the database.

member.name: T:Westwind.BusinessFramework.ResultListTypes
member.summary: ADO.NET Result types

member.name: T:Westwind.BusinessFramework.TrackingModes
member.summary: Determines how LINQ Change Tracking is applied

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.TrackingModes.Connected
member.summary: Uses a LINQ connected data context for change management whenever possible. Save and SubmitChanges operation is used to persist changes. In general this provides better performance for change tracking.

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.TrackingModes.Disconnected
member.summary: Creates a new DataContext for each operation and performs .Save operations by reconnecting to the DataContext.

member.name: T:Westwind.BusinessFramework.EfCodeFirst.EfCodeFirstBusinessBase`2
member.summary:
Business object base class that acts as a container for a base entity type and a DbContext instance. Subclasses of this business object should be used to implement most data related logic that deals with creating, updating, removing and querying of data use EF Code First.
The business object provides base CRUD methods like Load, NewEntity, Remove. The Save() method uses the EF specific context based SaveChanges which saves all pending changes (not just those for the current entity and its relations). As such these business objects should be used as atomically as possible and call Save() as often as possible to change pending data.

member.summary:
Validate() is used to validate business rules on the business object. Generally this method consists of a bunch of if statements that validate the data of the business object and adds any errors to the wwBusiness.ValidationErrors collection.
If the wwBusiness.AutoValidate flag is set to true causes Save() to automatically call this method. Must be overridden to perform any validation. Class wwBusiness Class ValidationErrorCollection
member.param: Optional entity to validate. Defaults to this.Entity
If true clears all validation errors before processing rules

member.summary:

This method should add any errors to the collection.

member.summary: Uses a LINQ connected data context for change management whenever possible. Save and SubmitChanges operation is used to persist changes. In general this provides better performance for change tracking.

member.summary: No Conflict resolution - nothing is done when conflicts occur. You can check Context.ChangeConflicts manually

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.EntityFramework.ConflictResolutionModes.ForceChanges
member.summary: Forces all changes to get written. Last one wins strategy

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.EntityFramework.ConflictResolutionModes.AbortChanges
member.summary: Aborts all changes and updates the entities with the values from the database.

member.name: T:Westwind.BusinessFramework.EntityFramework.BusinessObjectOptions
member.summary: Contains public options that can be set to affect how the business object operates

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.EntityFramework.BusinessObjectOptions.ThrowExceptions
member.summary: Determines whether exceptions are thrown on errors or whether error messages are merely set.

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.EntityFramework.BusinessObjectOptions.TrackingMode
member.summary:
Determines how LINQ is used for object tracking.
In connected mode all changes are tracked until SubmitChanges or Save is called. Save() reverts to calling SubmitChanges.
In disconnected mode a new context is created for each data operation and save uses Attach to reattach to a context.
Use Connected for much better performance use disconnected if you prefer atomic operations in the database with individual entities.

member.name: F:Westwind.BusinessFramework.EntityFramework.BusinessObjectOptions.ConnectionString
member.summary:
Optional Connection string that is used with the data context
Note: This property should be set in the constructor/Initialize of the business object.
If blank the default context connection string is used.

member.summary: Determines the default Conflict Resolution mode for changes submitted to the context.

member.name: T:Westwind.BusinessFramework.LinqToSql.DataContextFactory
member.summary:
This class provides several static methods for loading DataContext objects in a variety of ways. You can load the data context as normal one new instance at a time, or you can choose to use one of the scoped factory methods that can scope the DataContext to a WebRequest or a Thread context (in a WinForm app for example).
Using scoped variants can be more efficient in some scenarios and allows passing a DataContext across multiple otherwise unrelated components so that the change context can be shared.

member.name: M:Westwind.BusinessFramework.LinqToSql.DataContextFactory.GetDataContext``1
member.summary:
Creates a new Data Context for a specific DataContext type
Provided merely for compleness sake here - same as new YourDataContext()

member.name: M:Westwind.BusinessFramework.LinqToSql.DataContextFactory.GetDataContext``1(System.String)
member.summary:
Creates a new Data Context for a specific DataContext type with a connection string
Provided merely for compleness sake here - same as new YourDataContext()

member.name: M:Westwind.BusinessFramework.LinqToSql.DataContextFactory.GetWebRequestScopedDataContext``1
member.summary:
Creates a ASP.NET Context scoped instance of a DataContext. This static method creates a single instance and reuses it whenever this method is called.
This version creates an internal request specific key shared key that is shared by each caller of this method from the current Web request.

member.name: M:Westwind.BusinessFramework.LinqToSql.DataContextFactory.GetWebRequestScopedDataContext``1(System.String)
member.summary:
Creates a ASP.NET Context scoped instance of a DataContext. This static method creates a single instance and reuses it whenever this method is called.
This version lets you specify a specific key so you can create multiple 'shared' DataContexts explicitly.

member.name: T:Westwind.BusinessFramework.LinqToSql.BusinessObjectLinq`2
member.summary:
Base Business Object class that wrappers LINQ as a data access layer.
Assume: Operations work best and efficiently when tables have a TimeStamp field
Each business object maps to a primary Entity/Table, but can of course access other tables.

member.summary:
Initializes the business object explicitly.
This method can be overridden by any subclasses that want to customize the instantiation behavior and should call back to the base method
The core features this method performs are: - Create a new context - Creates the TableInfo
Overrides should create the Context FIRST then call back into the base Initialize

member.name: M:Westwind.BusinessFramework.LinqToSql.BusinessObjectLinq`2.Validate(`0)
member.summary:
Validate() is used to validate business rules on the business object. Generally this method consists of a bunch of if statements that validate the data of the business object and adds any errors to the wwBusiness.ValidationErrors collection.
If the wwBusiness.AutoValidate flag is set to true causes Save() to automatically call this method. Must be overridden to perform any validation. Class wwBusiness Class ValidationErrorCollection

member.name: M:Westwind.BusinessFramework.LinqToSql.BusinessObjectLinq`2.Validate

member.summary:
Method that should be overridden in a business object to handle actual validation. This method is called from the Validate method.

member.summary:
Object that handles conversion of queries into concreate types and data structures. Allows conversion of queries to a data reader, data table as well as the standard behaviors ToList(), ToArray() using the entity class as its input.
This routine is useful in that it provides object parameters the abillity to return output in a variety of ways which makes anonymous type result more usable outside of local scope.
